title: iOS Development Quiz - Part 2 (Segues, UIKit & Sensors)

questions.question: A segue is ______________
options: a one-way connection between source and destination view controllers
a two-way connection between source and destination view controllers
a multidirectional connection between multiple view controllers
this name does not have a meaning in iOS
questions.explanation: A segue represents a one-way transition from a source view controller to a destination view controller. To go back, you use unwind segues.

questions.question: Which of the following methods allows you to pass data from source view controller to the destination view controller?
questions.explanation: prepare(for segue:) is called before the segue executes, allowing you to access the destination view controller and pass data to it.

questions.question: This segue displays the view controller modally using the specified presentation and transition styles.
questions.explanation: The 'present modally' segue presents the destination view controller on top of the source, typically covering the entire screen.

questions.question: A ___________ defines a transition between two view controllers in your app's storyboard file.
questions.explanation: A segue is the iOS term for a transition defined in storyboard that connects two view controllers.

questions.question: What does the following function call do? performSegueWithIdentifier("SomeIdentifier", sender: self)
options: triggers transition defined by the segue with id SomeIdentifier
trigger transition to the view controller with id SomeIdentifier
trigger transition from the view controller with id SomeIdentifier
this call is incorrect, function does not exist
questions.explanation: performSegueWithIdentifier programmatically triggers the segue that has the specified identifier string in storyboard.

questions.question: If the segue looks like: source → destination. You define an unwind action method (that allows you to go back to source) in the destination view controller.
questions.explanation: Unwind segues are defined in the SOURCE (destination of the unwind), not the destination of the original segue. The @IBAction unwind method goes in the controller you want to return to.

questions.question: How can segues be executed in iOS application?
options: segues are not executed, they are symbolic
questions.explanation: Segues can be triggered automatically (by UI events like button taps) or programmatically using performSegue methods.

questions.question: This segue displays the new content using the showDetailViewController:sender: method of the target view controller.
questions.explanation: The 'show detail' segue uses showDetailViewController:sender: and is often used in split view controllers to show detail content.

questions.question: Which of the following can be used to display long lists of elements of the same type? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Both UITableView (single column lists) and UICollectionView (flexible grid layouts) are designed for displaying scrollable lists of data.

questions.question: Which setting changes the way in which slider sends the updates to the controller (either continuously or when the user is done changing)?
questions.explanation: The isContinuous property determines if UISlider sends value change events continuously while dragging or only when the user releases.

questions.question: Select all types of gesture recognizers from the following list.
questions.explanation: Gesture recognizers are categorized as discrete (one-time events like tap) or continuous (ongoing events like pan or pinch).

questions.question: What is the correct order of states for a gesture recognizer?
questions.explanation: Continuous gesture recognizers follow the state flow: began (gesture starts) → changed (gesture updates) → ended (gesture completes).

questions.question: What happens when a text field becomes a first responder?
options: the system automatically shows the keyboard and binds the input to the text field
the system automatically hides the keyboard and binds the input to the text field
the system automatically hides the keyboard and unbinds the input to the text field
the system automatically shows the keyboard and unbinds the input to the text field
questions.explanation: When a text field becomes first responder (gains focus), iOS automatically displays the keyboard and directs input to that field.

questions.question: Can you set the current value of the slider beyond the range min–max?
options: Yes, but only in the storyboard/interface builder (it will update one of the ends of the range)
Yes, but only programmatically (it will update one of the ends of the range)
Yes, but it will cause a runtime error
questions.explanation: Programmatically setting a slider value outside its range will automatically adjust (clamp) the min or max to accommodate the new value.

questions.question: You cannot customize the UISwitch component.
questions.explanation: UISwitch can be customized with properties like onTintColor, thumbTintColor, and you can change its appearance programmatically.

questions.question: Which of the following displays an editable text area in the interface?
questions.explanation: UITextView displays multi-line editable text. UITextField is single-line, and UILabel is non-editable.

questions.question: Which of the following functions hides the keyboard?
questions.explanation: Calling resignFirstResponder() on a text field or text view dismisses the keyboard by making it give up first responder status.

questions.question: What does it mean that a table view is a data driven view?
options: it generates the content based on the data from data source
it generates the content based on the user input
it is controlled by a data source
it is controlled by data entry
questions.explanation: Table views are data driven because they rely on a data source object that provides the number of rows and the content for each cell.

questions.question: Which package (module) is used to access the sensor data about motion and environment?
questions.explanation: CoreMotion is the iOS framework that provides access to accelerometer, gyroscope, magnetometer, and motion data.

questions.question: Permission to use location data has to be given each time the application tries to access the data.
questions.explanation: Once permission is granted, it persists until the user changes it in settings or the app is uninstalled. Permission doesn't need to be given every time.

questions.question: When is the permission to access the location requested?
options: Each time application wants to use location data
When the program requests it on runtime if not permanently given before
questions.explanation: Location permission is requested when your code first calls location services, if permission hasn't been permanently granted or denied before.

questions.question: How can energy consumption be minimized when using location services?
options: By using significant-change service and lowering the frequency of updates
questions.explanation: Using significant-change service (only updates on major location changes) and reducing update frequency significantly reduces battery consumption.

questions.question: Which sensor is used to measure the rate at which the device rotates around a specific axis?
questions.explanation: The gyroscope measures rotational velocity (rate of rotation) around the device's three axes.

questions.question: Permission to use location data has to be checked each time the application tries to access the data.
questions.explanation: While permission doesn't need to be requested each time, you should check the authorization status before accessing location data in case the user changed permissions.

questions.question: In what format is the acceleration data returned?
questions.explanation: Acceleration data is returned as a 3D vector with x, y, and z components representing acceleration along each axis.

questions.question: The values reported by the accelerometer are presented in increments of the gravitational acceleration. What does it mean?
questions.explanation: Accelerometer values are in units of g (Earth's gravity). A value of 1.0 equals 9.8 m/s², making the values easier to interpret relative to gravity.

questions.question: What is the unit of rotation used by sensors?
questions.explanation: Gyroscope data is returned in radians per second (rad/s), measuring the rate of rotation around each axis.

questions.question: What does accelerometer measure?
options: Change in position of the device
Change in orientation of the device
questions.explanation: The accelerometer measures acceleration - the rate of change in velocity along each axis (x, y, z).
